columns.text: In this exercise, we are going to learn about the factors which affect the option's value.

To start with, let us define an option. 

**Options** are types of financial contracts which give the holder the right, but not the obligation to buy or sell a specific asset at a predetermined price, on or before its date of expiration.

## Requirement 1

We are required to identify the factors that affect the option's value. 

The five factors that determine the option's value are the following: 

- Strike Price
- Current Stock Price
- Expiration Date
- Interest Rate
- Market Fluctuations

### Strike Price

The fixed price established on the financial contract at which the asset can be bought or sold is called the strike price. 

The strike price determines if the option will result in a gain or loss as compared to the current market prices.

### Current Stock Price

This is the present amount of the asset which is dependent on the market's volatility and financial condition. 

The price of the option is dependent on current stock prices because the value of stock prices has a direct relationship with the option's values.

### Expiration Date

This is the period wherein the holder can exercise his right to buy or sell the financial instrument. 

In the time period before the expiration, the option's value will depend either on the rise or decline of stock prices. The movement of the market along with the time determines the value of the option, which, maybe beneficial either on the part of the buyer or seller.

### Interest Rate

An interest rate is an economic factor which is the amount charged by the creditor to the principal amount loaned. 

Call options have a direct relationship with interest rates, meaning, that as interest rates increase, call option's value rise as well. 

On the other hand, the put option has an indirect relationship with interest rates; an increase in interest rates leads to a decline in put options.

###  Market Fluctuations

Stock prices changes over time, as well as the values of option. Market fluctuations are from the economic factors which affect the financial condition of the market as well. 

Analyzing the stock prices and market over time helps to reasonably visualize the option's value.

## Requirement 2

We are asked to identify which is more worthy between the American or European style put.

On an American-style put, the holders have the right to exercise their rights on or before the expiration date. This means that the holder can sell at any time or any day the option as long as the expiry date has not lapsed. The holder can observe the market and sell the option if he or she will result in a profit. 

On the other hand, European-style put has a fixed date and fixed price at which the option can be sold. Therefore, the holder has to sell it right away on the determined date, regardless if it will result in a gain or loss. The holder has no choice but to exercise his right when the date comes. 

Therefore, the American-style put is more worthy then European-style because the holder has more freedom when to exercise his rights.
